results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 11]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is a scenic tour of mostly seaside places, from Sydney Harbour and Port Phillip Bay to a brief look at Phillip Island. The Rankine family members feature and are joined by Bob Wootton late in the reel who contributes to their roadside picnic by cooking meat on a barbecue over a fire in a tin. Kenneth uses individual title cards to clearly point out the locations he is filming and fnishes sunset scenes. Kenneth also uses title cards to introduce each sequence.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:12:00 ‘Sydney and the Harbour’, views across the Harbour to residential areas; Kenneth appears to be filming from a vantage point on the water.

00:01:07:00 Harbour Bridge followed by shots of ferries and dockside buildings; a larger ship comes into view as well as Fort Denison Island and a longer shot of the Harbour Bridge.

00:03:20:00 ‘Manly’, the pier and some buildings.

00:03:40:00 shops and shoppers with the camera taking in the view down to the Harbour; beach scenes and a large ship in the distance.

00:04:48:00 ‘Blue Mountains from Echo Point’ is followed by dramatic views over the mountain ranges and rock formations.

00:05::39:00 the Rankines meeting some other travellers along a walking track.

00:05:51:00 scenes of a sports club and members relaxing, the men are in blazers.

00:06:16:00 ‘The Cascades Leura’, waterfalls, a footbridge and Mrs and Miss Rankine splashing at the foot of a waterfall.

00:07:41:00 a band playing in a large rotunda Spanish exhibition dancing for onlookers; this sequence also shows good examples of vintage bathers.

00:08:32:00 ‘St Kilda’, the St Kilda Botanical Gardens.

00:09:17:00 scenes looking across Pier Rd to the St Kilda Pier, kiosk and a yacht followed by shots of swimmers.

00:10:07:00 ‘At Elwood’ shows more examples of vintage bathing costumes with a beach coat and caps and launching a sail boat straight from the sand.

00:11:14:00 ‘At Mid Brighton’ small craft bobbing in shallow waters followed by a yacht race and Kenneth’s daughter with binoculars looking on.

00:13:07:00 ‘At Sandringham’ shows another sequence of swimmers, people sunbathing, sailboats and diving from what might be an old piece of a jetty, sitting on rocks on the shoreline; there are bathing boxes in the background on the beach.

00:16:50:00 a small boat being hoisted down from a shed and rolled on tracks into the water.

00:18:00:00 onwards we see the Rankines joined by Bob Wootton who contributes to their roadside picnic with his meat patties/ burgers, barbecued over a fire in a tin.

00:18:32:00 ‘Phillip Island’ is introduced with a postcard before coastal views and several shots of koalas in trees, the family wandering along a road.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows tugboats assisting ships into the piers at the Port of Melbourne and stars the “James Paterson” boat on which Kenneth is filming. The scenes in the reel show a lost world of shipping and the manual labour of port operations. The reel ends with the ‘James Paterson’ tugboat at the dock.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:30:00 title card ‘Pushing and Pulling’ and “starring James Paterson and Norman C. McBain”. Shortly after, we see a tugboat named ‘James Paterson’.

00:03:31:00 scenes of the workings of the tugboats in assisting ships in and out of port, stoking the engine fires, ships crews looking down from the great height of their vessels whilst the tugboats manoeuvre around them.

00:03:45:00 shots of boats and water and a large ship ‘Pipiriki’ leaving a pier and being towed by a tugboat from where Kenneth is filming, presumably on the ‘James Paterson’; we see shots of a harbour and ships and boats passing by as well as one the tugboat operator at the wheel.

00:04:07:00 we see the ship ‘Sanoma’ followed by men working lines on the tugboat alongside the ship.

00:07:55:00 ‘Melbourne Star’ ship, the ‘Wombat’ tugboat and ‘River Murumbidgee’.

00:09:15:00 we see a close up of rope work by the crew of the ‘Clan Macaulay’.

00:10:05:00 shows a great closeup shot of workers chatting on the tugboat.

00:11:50:00 a good shot of one of the dockside piers.

00:12:13:00 sequence from this point shows a ship hoisted into dry dock - Kenneth uses shots of the boat stop signal, a dry dock supply shop and the pier to emphasise the dry dock surrounds.

00:13:00:00 the scene changes to night time on the water followed by some passenger ships.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film contains scenes taken of the Rankine/Wootton children, filmed primarily at play in a garden. We see the children grow as the film tracks their growth over 3 years. Kenneth uses shots of flowers, trees and leaves throughout to separate scenes.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:10:00 title card “Now I am 3 & Look at Elizabeth 9 months”.

00:00:49:00 baby Elizabeth wearing a hat while sitting strapped into a coach-built pram.

00:01:27:00 family picnic, complete with picnic rug, wicker baskets, thermos flasks and folding chairs.

00:02:14:00 children in the garden shows us excellent examples of hand made and hand knitted children’s clothes. The images of Elizabeth at play show what fun small children can have with just a cardboard box.

00:03:52:00 close-up of a butterfly on foliage.

00:04:47:00 the children have grown and the eldest child is off to school as shown by his schoolbag. The Reel ends with a close-up of dad and the kids.

results.title: All that is solid
results.brief_description: This is a speculative documentary on the subject of the future of Australia. It is conceived as a series of competing discourses with visionaries, politicians, media commentators and others, who are variously optimistic and pessimistic. Interviews are interspersed with symbolic, imaginative drama.

Interviews are interspersed with symbolic, imaginative drama.

results.title: How AI sees me
results.brief_description: All those videogame and anime-inspired avatars you’re seeing on social media aren’t as innocent as they look. After uploading selfies and paying a small fee, the Lansa app can turn users into fairy princesses and rugged adventurers. But the AI-generated artworks are trained on the work of actual artists, some of whom fear their creativity will be replaced by computers. Non-White users have also reported that the app anglicised their features, while at other times it’s created sexualised images from pictures of children. Not to mention some believe that users are paying to train facial recognition intelligence and give up their personal data. So, look before you Lansa.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

All those videogame and anime-inspired avatars you’re seeing on social media aren’t as innocent as they look. After uploading selfies and paying a small fee, the Lensa app can turn users into fairy princesses and rugged adventurers. But the AI-generated artworks are trained on the work of actual artists, some of whom fear their creativity will be replaced by computers. Non-White users have also reported that the app anglicised their features, while at other times it’s created sexualised images from childhood photos. Not to mention some believe that users are paying to train facial recognition intelligence and giving up their personal data. So, look before you Lensa.

But the AI-generated artworks are trained on the work of actual artists, some of whom fear their creativity will be replaced by computers. Non-White users have also reported that the app anglicised their features, while at other times it’s created sexualised images from childhood pictures. Not to mention some believe that users are paying to train facial recognition intelligence and giving up their personal data. So, look before you Lensa.

results.title: Access Video 1973-1982
results.creator_credit: Helen Eisler and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
The results of a reserach project funded by the Australian Film Commission and the Commonwealth Employment Programme this title presents highlights of programmes of historical importance, demonstrating the growth and maturing of independent video which in turn reflects the development of community and political activity during the seventies.

During this decade 12 access video centres were established. This title shows highlights of proigrammes made by various centres.

results.title: Don't Shoot the Messenger
results.brief_description: “Visuals recorded live at a digital meditation in cyberspace performed during the Mayday dance party 1993. A series of computers and cameras were interconnected, manipulated realtime and projected.” Sourced from VHS cover slip for Don’t Shoot the Messenger

results.title: Cyberthon I: For the Mind, Body and Soul
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ was the first guerrilla TV broadcast event of its namesake following the success of the Cyberdelia broadcast a year earlier. Conceptualised as a ‘marathon cyber’ event, ‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ saw a group of artists broadcast, remix, VJ and DJ mastered footage, experimental Amiga graphics and electronic art alongside performers and a live band at RMITV’s studio in Melbourne. Collaborator and curator to the events, Adem Jaffers said this is where the Cyberthon events really began and over the next four years they would expand in scope to feature over 300 VJ’s, DJ’s, artists, performers and collaborators. 

Visual Artists: Nuero (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Troy Innocent, Dale Nason and Elena Popa), Future Films (Jeff Jaffers), Interscreen (Kimberley Hughes), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi)

Audio Artists: Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac and Terence ‘H20’ Ho), Third Eye (Ollie Olsen), Acid Death Bed (Darren Porter and Paul Wain), Baby Lemonade Lemar (Andrea), Captain ROM

Performers: Taz (Tasilim Emiabata), Star (Raquel Webb), Lizette Broulathaki

‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Disney Masterclass with Roy Conli and Glen Keane
results.brief_description:
Disney Animator Glen Keane and Producer Roy Conli presented a special Masterclass sharing their behind-the-scenes insights and love of the animation process.
Glen Keane has been with the Walt Disney Studios for over 25 years and is best known for his character animations for feature films such as ‘The Little Mermaid’, ‘Aladdin’, ‘Beauty and the Beast’, ‘Tarzan’, and ‘Tangled’. He reflects on the inspirations for some of his characters and expressing yourself through drawing.
Roy Conli is the producer of the Disney feature animated film, ‘Tangled’, based on the story of Rapunzel. He explains the role of the producer and the line between creating a safe and fertile environment for artists and getting a film made on time and within budget.
